title: slides
text:

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

diamonds |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = carat)) +
  geom_density()









diamonds |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = carat)) +
  geom_freqpoly()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.










Unexamined life is not worth living!
– Socrates

title: Can.Do.So
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ISLR)
library(performance)
library(ggeffects)
library(sjPlot)
library(gtsummary)
library(equatiomatic)
set.seed(9)
d <- Wage |> 
  filter(wage < 200 & age < 60) |> 
  sample_n(100, .by = education)
m <- lm(wage ~ age + year + jobclass + education, data = d)
summary(m)


Call:
lm(formula = wage ~ age + year + jobclass + education, data = d)

Residuals:
   Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
-54.90 -17.73   0.18  13.57  72.47 

Coefficients:
                              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                 -1166.8193  2632.5491  -0.443 0.658641    
age                             0.8722     0.2879   3.029 0.003182 ** 
year                            0.6086     1.3124   0.464 0.643906    
jobclass2. Information         -0.4755     5.4296  -0.088 0.930405    
education2. HS Grad            11.4982     9.0919   1.265 0.209188    
education3. Some College       23.1037     8.7640   2.636 0.009840 ** 
education4. College Grad       30.7209     8.9325   3.439 0.000878 ***
education5. Advanced Degree    29.3441    11.4902   2.554 0.012298 *  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 26.08 on 92 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.2396,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.1818 
F-statistic: 4.142 on 7 and 92 DF,  p-value: 0.0005317

title: Can.Do.So
text:
Check model assumptions visually

check_model(m)







check_normality(m)

OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.234).

check_heteroscedasticity(m)

OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.083).



set.seed(9)
d2 <- Wage |> 
  filter(wage < 200 & age < 60) |> 
  group_by(education) |>
  sample_n(100) |> 
  ungroup()


m2 <- lm(wage ~ age + year + jobclass + education, data = d2)
summary(m2)


Call:
lm(formula = wage ~ age + year + jobclass + education, data = d2)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-96.773 -16.542  -1.439  14.051  69.929 

Coefficients:
                              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                 -2127.5724  1134.5286  -1.875   0.0613 .  
age                             0.5601     0.1099   5.095 4.98e-07 ***
year                            1.0916     0.5657   1.930   0.0542 .  
jobclass2. Information          3.3536     2.4528   1.367   0.1722    
education2. HS Grad             6.4143     3.5926   1.785   0.0748 .  
education3. Some College       18.6562     3.6552   5.104 4.76e-07 ***
education4. College Grad       34.3258     3.6994   9.279  < 2e-16 ***
education5. Advanced Degree    45.4886     3.7987  11.975  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 25.35 on 492 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.3675,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.3585 
F-statistic: 40.84 on 7 and 492 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



check_model(m2)







check_normality(m2)

Warning: Non-normality of residuals detected (p < .001).

check_heteroscedasticity(m2)

Warning: Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance) detected (p < .001).

title: Can.Do.So
text:
Visualize predictions

ggeffect(m2)

$age
# Predicted values of wage

age | Predicted |         95% CI
--------------------------------
 15 |     93.26 |  87.13,  99.40
 20 |     96.07 |  90.92, 101.21
 25 |     98.87 |  94.67, 103.07
 30 |    101.67 |  98.33, 105.00
 40 |    107.27 | 105.02, 109.52
 45 |    110.07 | 107.72, 112.42
 50 |    112.87 | 109.98, 115.76
 60 |    118.47 | 113.89, 123.05



Not all rows are shown in the output. Use `print(..., n = Inf)` to show
  all rows.



$year
# Predicted values of wage

year | Predicted |         95% CI
---------------------------------
2003 |    104.99 | 101.12, 108.86
2004 |    106.08 | 103.05, 109.11
2005 |    107.17 | 104.76, 109.59
2006 |    108.27 | 106.03, 110.50
2007 |    109.36 | 106.79, 111.93
2008 |    110.45 | 107.18, 113.72
2009 |    111.54 | 107.39, 115.69


$jobclass
# Predicted values of wage

jobclass       | Predicted |         95% CI
-------------------------------------------
1. Industrial  |    106.30 | 102.88, 109.71
2. Information |    109.65 | 106.50, 112.80


$education
# Predicted values of wage

education          | Predicted |         95% CI
-----------------------------------------------
1. < HS Grad       |     87.12 |  82.01,  92.24
2. HS Grad         |     93.54 |  88.48,  98.59
3. Some College    |    105.78 | 100.76, 110.80
4. College Grad    |    121.45 | 116.42, 126.47
5. Advanced Degree |    132.61 | 127.46, 137.76


attr(,"class")
[1] "ggalleffects" "list"        
attr(,"model.name")
[1] "m2"



ggpredict(m2, terms = "age")

# Predicted values of wage

age | Predicted |        95% CI
-------------------------------
 15 |     70.65 | 63.03,  78.27
 20 |     73.45 | 66.58,  80.32
 25 |     76.25 | 70.03,  82.47
 30 |     79.05 | 73.35,  84.75
 40 |     84.65 | 79.45,  89.86
 45 |     87.45 | 82.17,  92.74
 50 |     90.25 | 84.68,  95.83
 60 |     95.86 | 89.20, 102.51

Adjusted for:
*      year =       2006.00
*  jobclass = 1. Industrial
* education =  1. < HS Grad



Not all rows are shown in the output. Use `print(..., n = Inf)` to show
  all rows.



ggeffect(m2) |> 
  plot() |> 
  sjPlot::plot_grid()

Warning in sjPlot::plot_grid(plot(ggeffect(m2))): Not enough tags labels in
list. Using letters instead.









extract_eq(m2, wrap = T, terms_per_line = 4)
\[
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wage} &= \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{age}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{year}) + \beta_{3}(\operatorname{jobclass}_{\operatorname{2.\ Information}})\ + \\
&\quad \beta_{4}(\operatorname{education}_{\operatorname{2.\ HS\ Grad}}) + \beta_{5}(\operatorname{education}_{\operatorname{3.\ Some\ College}}) + \beta_{6}(\operatorname{education}_{\operatorname{4.\ College\ Grad}}) + \beta_{7}(\operatorname{education}_{\operatorname{5.\ Advanced\ Degree}})\ + \\
&\quad \epsilon
\end{aligned}
\]
